revised_title: Investigating the Coagulation of Lymph and Serum in Blood
tldr: The author investigates the degree of heat required to coagulate lymph and serum in blood, and examines the causes of inflammatory crust formation. The study concludes that the coagulable lymph in dog blood coagulates between 114°F and 120.5°F, while the serum requires a higher heat of 160°F to coagulate. The author also finds that inflammation may actually reduce the blood's coagulation tendency, contrary to previous beliefs.
